Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: STEM Workforce Training: A Quasi-Experimental Approach Using the Effects of Research Funding

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
EHR Core Research
Workforce Development

This is a collaborative project involving Ohio State University (lead institution), Pennsylvania State University, American Institutes for Research, University of Illinois-Urbana, and the University of Iowa. The project examines the impact of different research funding structures on the training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows and the impact of their subsequent outcomes. The rationale for the study is the recognition that research teams are organized differently in composition, size, and reliance of graduate students versus postdoctoral fellows. In addition, funding agencies change the structure of science training by creating programs that ?encourage? interdisciplinary groups, multi-university collaborations, or large research centers that focus on specific research questions. However, little research has been done about how these factors shape the career preparation of STEM professionals.

The PIs will begin by examining the different contexts of research funding and training and then (1) relate measures of team structure to the structure of funding to determine the extent to which funding agency policies shape research teams and (2) capture the trajectories of the students and postdoctoral fellows during and after their contact with the teams to quantify how the structure of teams affects training. They will use longitudinal administrative data that to capture information about sources of funding for the training and support of Ph.D.s and Postdocs from 13 major research institutions that participate in the Committee on Institutional Cooperation. They will then identify the nature of the research training through a text analysis of pertinent documents and use a quasi-experimental design to estimate the causal impact of the structure of research and length of training on trainee outcomes.

The project will have broad implications for the entire field of STEM education policy and research. The underlying algorithms and tools will be made available to the academic research community and can be leveraged to link internal human resources data sets to external data sets. This new data infrastructure also will facilitate the assessment of the effects of research investments on research productivity as well as undergraduate and graduate curriculum development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Research Report

Christopher Morphew (PI)

This award has helped us to develop several completed and still-pending research products, each yielding important new findings. Our aim in this research was to examine research-team structure and to investigate whether women were systematically occupy disadvantageous positions on research teams. We integrated work on social capital, social network analysis, and research on women’s roles in science to study whether women regularly occupied positions on research teams that were conceptually linked with less social capital. Recent work has found that women, at all stages in academic careers, commonly assume a greater share of task-based work when compared with men. Men, on the other hand, tend to engage in conceptual and ideational work. These findings align with prior work that women in the academy often perform a greater share of service duties.

Our research sought a conceptual explanation for persistent gender roles in academic work, particularly in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields. We used UMETRICS data in order to construct research-team networks. We then linked data with human resources data that identified an individual’s gender, race/ethnicity, and position title. With these data, we examined whether gender was associated with network measures of social capital, controlling for other covariates including position, number of research grants,

In an initial conference paper prepared for the Consortium of Higher Education Researchers (CHER), we focused on female graduate students. Findings suggested that graduate-student women more commonly occupied network positions associated with lower levels of social capital. Specifically, women had access to fewer individuals throughout the network than men, indicating that they have fewer resources to draw upon.

We additionally presented a separate paper at the American Educational Research Association (AERA) Annual Meeting in 2017. This manuscript reported findings indicating that female graduate students more commonly worked with female faculty members. Because female faculty also had limited research networks, female graduate students additionally had more constrained connections. At the same time, men who are connected to female faculty-members have even broader networks because they additionally work with male faculty-members and can access those networks as well. Collectively, these results indicate that women more frequently occupy disadvantageous network positions, aligning with work finding that female graduate students are often on the fringes of research teams and more commonly are tasked with technical lab work rather than more conceptually-oriented work.

These studies have important implications for scientific work. First, this work calls upon principal investigators to be cognizant of the division of labor on their research teams, as well as the gender balance on research teams. Ensuring that women have equitable access to social networks that provide resources essential for academic success can improve the effectiveness of public spending on scientific training. As it stands, these findings suggest that women and men face differential training environments. Institutions should take steps to reduce inequities by increasing female representation on research teams. At the same time, institutions should increase female representation on the faculty in STEM fields. We are in the process of integrating and revising these manuscripts for submission to a peer-reviewed journal and developing a policy brief with the intent to influence institutional practices.
